prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All of the sources are well-known point source calibrators, so observing a separate phase calibrator is unnecessary. Moreover, we don't care about the absolute flux calibration - we are just measuring fractional absorption against the continuum level, whatever it may be - so it's not necessary to include a flux calibrator either.
However, there is a known bug in OT that causes the "User Defined Calibration" to crash. According to the answers to HelpDesk ticket #4564 on 07:07 PM of Dec 2rd "We have discovered a possible OT bug affecting validation of user-defined calibration requests. We are working on it and I will update you as soon as possible. Meanwhile if you want to go ahead and get your proposal past validation you could accept the observatory standard calibration and just describe in the technical justification form the details of the user-defined calibration that you wish to use. If the bug does not get fixed in time for you to update your proposal the issue will be handled properly at the review stage if you have fully described in your TJ form."
The total time should be much less than the time estimated by ALMA Observation Tool.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The common, familiar tracer for molecular hydrogen (H2) is CO emission. However, H2 without CO emission, called "Dark Molecular Gas", turns out to be surprisingly abundant, roughly equal in mass to the more familiar CO-traced H2. Even so, many astronomers are only dimly aware of its existence. Dark Molecular Gas represents the transition between atomic gas and the familiar form of H2--the initial stages of star formation, which lies at the very heart of modern astrophysics. To explore the conditions that lead to this transition, we propose a broad frontal attack on Dark molecular gas, consisting of (1) using ALMA to measure the lowest three rotational lines of HCO+ and CO in absorption against the two strong mm-wave continuum sources 3C454.3 and 3C207; (2) using ALMA to survey the (J=1-0) lines of HCO+ and CO against 15 strong mm-wave continuum sources; and (3) mapping CO, HCO+, and HI emission using various telescopes around the world. In absorption, ALMA can accomplish in minutes what requires hours at CARMA, making such a systematic study feasible.
